title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Heart Association (New York, NY)
Interview Descriptions: My interview process was extremely efficient. I was asked questions that appropriately matched my background and connected instantly with my future bosses! The entire thing took less than a week to bring me on to the program.
Interview Questions: They asked about my experience through college, along with why I chose this position based on that experience.

title: Communications Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Cleveland, OH)
Interview Descriptions: Overall the process was thorough but drawn out. It started with a video interview, followed by a call with a recruiter, and then two zoom interviews with the hiring manager and various other team members. I applied in early March and it took almost a month to be contacted for the video interview and each interview after that was spaced at least 2 weeks apart. The interviewers were very warm and welcoming and asked thought provoking questions.
Interview Questions: What’s something I wouldn’t know about you from your resume?

title: Development Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: There were several interview steps for this position including self-video recording, HR phone calls, and subsequent interviews with the manager as well as the team members that I would be working with.
Interview Questions: 1. How do you handle and prioritize multiple tasks given to you at once? 2. What do you think your responsibilities would consist of?

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Heart Association (Tallahassee, FL)
Interview Descriptions: It was a very relaxed and general interview of education, past experience, and interest in the position. I was interviewing for an intern role, so they did not expect too much.
Interview Questions: What experience do you have in event planning?

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: During my interview, I met with both the hiring manager and the department manager of the department I was applying to be a part of! Very relaxed and accommodating atmosphere that definitely reflects the overall vibe of the organization.
Interview Questions: Why the American Heart Association?

title: Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: Interview was a straightforward process with no surprise questions. The panel was informative to the process and was not difficult. General questions asked about background and related experience. Did not go past another round.
Interview Questions: Background information Why you want position

title: Development Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Tampa, FL) in Feb 2023
Interview Descriptions: The recruiters are professional. The process moved swiftly. They have excellent onboarding tools and interview to offer is within a week. Questions are specific to the role that you are seeking. Positive experience.
Interview Questions: The questions were focused specifically around the type of role I was seeking. (Fundraising etc)

title: Data Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Jan 2023
Interview Descriptions: Asked various statistical and machine learning questions, such as explaining regularization and biases in machine learning models. Also asked questions dealing with missing data. First interview was a phone interview that went over resume and background as well as asking different questions depending on technologies present in resume.
Interview Questions: What is L1 and L2 regularization and what do they do?

title: Kitchen Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Remote) in Dec 2022
Interview Descriptions: There is an initial phone call with a general recruiter, a video interview, an interview with the team, and then another interview with the executive team. The video interview allows you a few chances to re-record your response which definitely takes some of the pressure off.
Interview Questions: In the video interview they asked to describe a time there were multiple different managerial styles you had to balance and how you did it.

title: Accountant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: Screen call, self interview Video and two in person interviews. Straight forward questions and typical interview questions. Recruiter kept informed throughout the whole process. The whole process took a while to reach decision.
Interview Questions: Tell me about yourself. Why this position?

title: Developmental Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Nov 2022
Interview Descriptions: Interview process was pretty organized. 3 rounds of interviews and within a week or two apart. Recruiter was good at keeping me in the loop, overall great experience. Communication fantastic.
Interview Questions: Why do I want to work for American Heart Association.

title: Contract Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: The interview was a panel interview with three people. The questions were focused on past experience, skills, and behavioral based questions. None of the questions were really difficult and the interviewers were very nice and welcoming. The second interview was very informal with more of a focus on why I should choose AHA which was extremely refreshing. Communication through tour the process was great.
Interview Questions: Tell us about why this job would be a good fit for you?

title: Development Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Dallas, TX) in Sept 2022
Interview Descriptions: First there was a 1-sided timed video interview. I recommend not taking multiple tries because you could get worse each time. Next step was a phone call with a recruiter. The next step was a phone interview with hiring manager.
Interview Questions: Fundraising goal you are most proud of

title: Development Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Minneapolis, MN) in Sept 2022
Interview Descriptions: I went through 4 interviews (entry level role) with different members of the team and was ghosted regarding my interview for the position. Even after reaching out, I heard nothing.
Interview Questions: How would you make a sale to get your numbers up? How do you work under pressure?

title: Project Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Jul 2022
Interview Descriptions: The process was organized and moved swiftly. I interviewed with HR, my supervisor, then my supervisor along with their boss. Each person was super nice and direct regarding this position.
Interview Questions:
Q: We often work with people outside our department on projects. What would you do if you had a deadline coming up and they weren't responding with the information you were needing? 

Q: Why should we hire you?

title: Development Director Interview
Application Type: The process took 1 week. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: I enjoyed the entire interview process, beginning with the initial phone interview through meeting virtually with key leadership. Everyone I had an opportunity to connect with was thoughtful, helpful and provided intentional and meaningful feedback.
Interview Questions:
What interested you about the position? 
What do you know about the organization?
What was the largest gift I secured?
These were just a few questions that led to a robust and interactive conversation.

title: Director of Marketing and Communications Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Jun 2022
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was an overall great experience. The interview panel was welcoming and open to addressing all questions and inquiries. Additionally, the interview was challenging and required me to provide thought-provoking responses.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work at the American Heart Association?

title: Mission Advancement Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1+ week. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Dallas, TX) in Jun 2022
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was very efficient.  I was contacted by HR in response to my submitted application to set up a quick phone call.  She arranged an interview with the hiring manager within a few days of our phone call, I interviewed with the team and was told I would hear from someone.  HR called me within 24 hours with feedback and asked for mine.  We discussed timelines for next steps and then I was contacted that they would be extending an offer which happened within a few days.  Overall they were easy to talk to and I felt they wanted to make sure I was happy as well as filling the position.
Interview Questions:
Why does this position appeal to you?
Why do you want to work for the American Heart Association?
Why do you think your experience is a good fit?

title: Director of Development Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Los Angeles, CA)
Interview Descriptions: Contacted via email that was a no reply to do a recorded interview with ICIMS app. I would like to add this app is very outdated, the quality is not great on audio nor visual. It is prerecorded with 5 questions. Everyone that asks the question overly asks a question with an emphasis how great it is to work for this company, how great the benefits are. Did my recording, submitted it, and had to follow up by over reaching on LinkedIn. No offer given. I personally wouldn’t bother applying unless you have heavy experience in fundraising. Asking for a 5 year business plan in our recent economy for a non-profit is absolutely ridiculous. I’ve worked for multi-billion dollar company’s who haven’t even asked for a 5 year business plan.
Interview Questions: How would you execute a 5 year business plan

title: Development Director Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Durham, NC) in May 2022
Interview Descriptions: I will start at AHA in a few weeks and their interviewing/onboarding process has been a breath of fresh air compared to my previous employers. Everything leading up to the interviews was clearly communicated and the interviews themselves were professionally handled. Onboarding has been a breeze so far, it seems like they are truly excited to bring me on. Can't wait to get started!
Interview Questions: They asked me how I handled stress.

title: School Fundraising/Youth Market Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association in May 2022
Interview Descriptions:
The interview process was very concise and moved quickly. First interview was with a Senior VP and then the second interview was with the Senior VP and a VP.  The second interview was two hours and there were quite a bit of scenario and experience questions. 

Due to scheduling, I did not talk to the recruiter until the end of the process, but everyone was very willing to answer questions during the process and responses to emails about scheduling were very prompt. After the job offer, all items have also gone well and very easy to complete and ask any final questions.
Interview Questions: Tell us about a time you were told no.

title: Marketing Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: I have to say that I was really disappointed in their interview process. I was interviewing with 4 different companies at the same time, and this was by far the poorest of experiences. It started with receiving an impersonal email requesting that I follow a link to conduct a recorded zoom interview, with pre-recorded questions. It felt very cold, impersonal, one-sided, and extremely awkward just staring at yourself answering questions. It didn't allow me to ask any of MY questions, or get an actual FEEL for any of the employees and the culture. The questions were also very stale, old-school, behavioral interviewing questions. I’m extremely relieved that most companies no longer ask these types of questions and, instead, use the interview time as a “get-to-know-you” type meeting. I received a templated email confirmation from the recruiter to verify that she received my recorded interview, saying they'd notify me of next steps, and then I never heard from them again. I was surprised to find out that of the 4 different companies I was interviewing with, AHA was the poorest experience; had you asked me prior, I would’ve guessed they would’ve been #1. I stand behind the American Heart Association and applaud their efforts for those affected by heart disease. I hope that they see the need to revise their hiring tactics so they can get the strongest candidates in the door, to further their mission. This process doesn’t seem to be conducive to that.
Interview Questions: A lot of situational type questions.

title: Community CPR Manager Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: A very pleasant 3-step process: 1) initial interview with HR, 2) a one-way video interview with 4 questions, and 3) an interview with the two who would supervise me. It was efficient and pleasant all around.
Interview Questions: What was a stress-filled situation and how did you handle it?

title: Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: The first round was a pre-recorded interview, then I met with members of the local leadership team as well as my supervisor for my 2nd round interview. And for the final interview it was a brief meeting with the EVP of my local region. Overall it was a great process, there was thorough communication throughout the entire process.
Interview Questions: What would you do to learn the lay of the land in the region you'd be overseeing?

title: Project Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Mar 2022
Interview Descriptions:
A long process to get to the final round. First is the pre-recorded video questions you answer.  Then is the prescreening phone interview with a recruiter.  Next is a video interview with the hiring manager.  Then a video interview with a group.  And finally there was a video interview with the hiring manager's boss.  Overall, a very long process.  I had to constantly reach out to the recruiter for an update on the process.

I found everyone very pleasant and would definitely apply to another position.
Interview Questions:
Why did you apply for this position?

Lots of scenario-type questions related to the job itself.

title: Community Impact Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Mar 2022
Interview Descriptions:
It was a fourth interview process overall that took roughly a month from start to an offer. After each step below there was typically 1-5 days until contact about the next step in the process. The recruiter was wonderful and kept me in the loop throughout. 

1st "interview"- Video response system. You are asked pre-recorded questions. You have a couple chances to record each of your video answers. The questions are pretty standard interview questions and it took roughly 30 minutes to complete. After this interview I was not asked any of the predictable interview questions, they were mostly situational and related to my specific experience/resume. 

2nd- This video interview was with the person who will manage me. There were a lot of questions about my resume/experience and how it relates to the position. 

3rd- This interview was with the Executive Director, the person who manages my manager. She asked me additional questions about my resume and experience and described the position in more detail. 

4th/Final Interview- This was with two SVPs who asked me more specific examples of my experience and how it relates to this role. 

I wouldn't consider any of the above interviews easy, or overtly challenging. They were right in the middle, and all interviewers in the process were polite, friendly, and informative.
Interview Questions: I cannot recall specific interview questions.

title: Community Impact Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (North Augusta, SC) in Mar 2022
Interview Descriptions: The process was simple to navigate, convenient, and guided by great support staff.  There were a number of steps; but, one point of contact helped a great deal.  The communication was great.
Interview Questions: Didn't notate questions asked.  The first, virtual video upload interview was more formal/traditional questions.  The additional interviews were less formal.  There was less of a script and more of a dialogue between professionals about the agency, position, and myself, as a candidate.

title: Event Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: Very simple and straightforward interview process. Nothing too complicated or from left field. Enjoyed it being quite relaxed and no pressure! It was an interview for an intern position, so this is likely very different from a paid position.
Interview Questions: They asked about my education background and why I was interested in the non-profit sector.

title: Marketing Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Dallas, TX) in Feb 2022
Interview Descriptions: Very efficient interview process-- 1 video recording and 2 zoom calls.  I'd been evaluating other opportunities simultaneously, and the decisive interview process at AHA spoke volumes to me. The team was also very considerate and asked me questions about my life, my hobbies, etc, as well as my professional experience. It made for a very personable process, and gave a good indication of the culture fit.
Interview Questions:
How would you get up to speed learning a completely new topic/ subject matter?  

How do you navigate projects with many decision-makers, many of whom may not be informed about best practices?

title: Development Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (West Palm Beach, FL) in Feb 2022
Interview Descriptions: I completed an online pre-recorded interview. They had a video asking a question to which I received a few seconds to think about it and record my response. You can re-record and use your best answer. I then was contacted by the recruiter to have an interview with the hiring manager followed by an interview with the Executive Director. The final interview included both of them and the VP.
Interview Questions: They ask me to walk them through my resume.

title: Special Events Administrator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was pretty long and thorough. It began with a phone interview, questionnaire, video interview, Skype panel interview, then in-person interview.  Everyone was professional and asked great questions. It was a lengthy process however.
Interview Questions: Tell me about a challenging time in your career and how you overcame it.

title: Development Director Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: The interview process overall is very smooth at the AHA. You start with a self-recorded interview, then move on to speaking with who would be your supervisor (VP of Development), your supervisors boss (Executive Director), and then the regional SVP of Development. Overall, a total of 4 interviews including the self-recorded interview. Everything is coordinated through an HR personnel which made communications super easy and efficient. Rigorous, but great process!
Interview Questions: How do you stay organized to achieve goals?

title: Community Impact Director Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: Virtual interview consisted of six interview questions provided by various staff members that you had to answer one at a time. You had to record your answers to these questions and submit the best video recording
Interview Questions: I honestly don't quite remember

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Jan 2022
Interview Descriptions: Begins with a scheduled phone call with recruiter, if you make it past the first round then you have a scheduled video call with the hiring manager. The process was straightforward and easy. The first call was to really get to know your interest in the organization and the second was to see how well of a fit you could be for the hiring office.
Interview Questions: Tell me about a difficult experience at work and how you resolved it

title: Development Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Jan 2022
Interview Descriptions: Easy! Phone and Zoom appointments with flexible schedules to set it all up. Very nice and easy to navigate. I felt like they really wanted to find the right person… not just hurry to fill the position. I had a chance to also ask questions and felt like the response was genuine.
Interview Questions: What type of work culture do you thrive in?

title: Marketing Communications Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Jan 2022
Interview Descriptions: I started with an online application, resume and cover letter, contact from recruiter, recorded interview, one on one zoom interview, in person group interview, and finally a group zoom interview.
Interview Questions: Why I was leaving my old company and why I wanted to work for them; what did I have to offer them.

title: Procurement Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions:
From the initial interview, it only took a few weeks for me to be hired. 

The overall interview was simple and straight forward.
There were your average situational questions, all were easy to navigate.
Interview Questions:
Tell me how you hold others accountable.
How do you manage multiples responsibilities.

title: Development Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Dec 2021
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was incredibly easy and quick throughout.  Each person I encountered throughout the process was very professional and personable.  More importantly, they were very forthcoming with information so I feel I was given pertinent information before I even had to ask.
Interview Questions: A thoughtful question that was asked  was, "How do you like to be managed?".  I think that is the first time I have ever been asked that and I was impressed.

title: Office Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (West Palm Beach, FL) in Nov 2021
Interview Descriptions: My interview process was seamless. The recruiter always followed up with me and made sure I knew what to expect next. It started with a digital interview. The recruiter reached out to me after and then scheduled my interviews with the managers.
Interview Questions: Give us an example of when you used your skills in your previous/current position?

title: Human Resources Partner Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: The recruiter was not terribly thorough with her follow up and  follow through during the interview process. The interview  questions that were asked were irrelevant to the position. I would have expected more from this company.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Development Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: Met with multiple people in the organization. It was a longer interview process but very informative and helpful! I also had to take an e-skills test and a questionnaire about myself.
Interview Questions: They asked about multi-tasking and use of data entry applications!

title: Community Impact Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at American Heart Association (West Palm Beach, FL) in Oct 2021
Interview Descriptions: Five step interview process. I completed a video interview, interview with VP of Health Strategies, then with VP and CEO, this was then concluded with an interview with two Regional Directors. During this process, a background check was completed and I was asked to submit 3 reference included a direct supervisor.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work at the American Heart Association?

title: Director of Development Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Oct 2021
Interview Descriptions: Applied online, received a screening call with a recruiter.  Recruiter was aggressive, barking and talking over me when I attempted to answer questions. AHA has an extremely mercenary sounding fundraising strategy that seems designed to motivate performance through fear and, apparently, creates adversarial dynamics on the team.  That plus the video questions was a big nope from me.
Interview Questions: Largest ask you've made and secured

title: Development Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1+ week. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Jacksonville, FL) in Sept 2021
Interview Descriptions: Quick, easy and thorough. Three separate interviews - video questions, hiring manager, Executive Director & SVP. Required to have 3-5 references complete a questionnaire, 2 of which had to be current or past managers. HR recruiter responded quickly to questions and was pleasant to work with!
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work at AHA?

title: Development Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Aug 2021
Interview Descriptions:
1. On-demand/recorded one-way video interview - allowed 1 re-record for each question, but it was still unnerving
2. Live video interview via Zoom with ED & Regional VP -great interaction, great people
3. Live video interview with Sr. VP of Development -great interaction, very relaxed
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work for AHA? Give an example of a challenging work situation you experienced and how you dealt with it. Tell about your fundraising experience. Etc.

title: Communications and Marketing Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Jacksonville, FL) in Aug 2021
Interview Descriptions: I applied via LinkedIn August 20th and within 24 hours I was emailed asking to complete a one-way video interview with the link. I never did one before, so I researched and prepped like crazy (you have 4 days to complete it). The 4-5 questions were pre-recorded and you record your answer within a time limit.  It’s awkward at first, but you can watch your response before submitting. If you don’t like your first take, you have one additional try.  Before you begin that second try, you have all the time in the world to practice/prepare before hitting the timer. After submitting my responses I week later I was contacted to set up a 30 minute phone interview with the Executive Director and Regional VP, however he couldn’t make it. The interview was great - I felt like I really connected with the executive director, who is whom I’d report to. She explained the position and asked her questions - it felt more like a 30 minute conversation than an interview. About 48 hours later I was asked by my recruiter for a zoom interview the following week with the same two people for one hour. 2 weeks later I emailed for a status update and was then scheduled within 24 hours  for another zoom interview, this time with the Senior VP of Health Strategies in Tampa Bay and Senior VP of Development in Orlando for one hour. I felt like they really reviewed my resume beforehand as they asked a few specific questions to my cover letter and former employers/projects I worked on, which I really appreciated. I really connected with them both as we all had similar career backgrounds. I was offered the position 4 days later. The entire process took 6 weeks. My recruiter was amazing and responded to every email or question I had within 24 hours and she kept me updated after each step in the process. As soon as I accepted their offer, I was provided information to get the onboard process going and my first day is two weeks later.
Interview Questions:
1. How does your past experiences relate to this position?

2. How would you handle multiple requests coming in with very similar deadlines?

3. Have you ever handled a crisis situation before, and if so, how did you go about doing that?

4. Are you connected to our local media and have any relationships with them?

5. Name your greatest strength and weakness?

6. Why do you want to work for AHA?

title: Communications Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Aug 2021
Interview Descriptions: Applied online in their platform. About a week later received an invitation for a one-way video interview that had to be completed within 4 days. A week after that, received a phone interview request with a recruiting director, then the following week did an interview with the Executive Director and VP for Communications for the region. Received a decision two business days later.
Interview Questions: Talk about a time you had to manage competing priorities.

title: Director of Communications and Marketing Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Dallas, TX) in Aug 2021
Interview Descriptions: This was a fourth step process that lasted about 6 weeks. The initial interview is a pre-recorded video, and you record and submit your response. If selected, you’ll speak with HR. My role is market level, so I had interviews with the local Executive Director, regional Regional VP of Development, Regional VP of Communications and a VP executive. Everything was via teams, and so wasn’t able to visit the office before accepting the role, however everyone was respectful and each step had at least a “lag week” before the next interview.
Interview Questions: Tell me about a time you had a disagreement about a project with a coworker and what did you do.

title: Event Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Aug 2021
Interview Descriptions: Submitted an online application and received an email for a one-way video interview the same day. Completed the video interview (5 questions with 3 minutes to answer) and heard back from HR a week later. I was asked to do a Zoom interview with the immediate supervisor and their manager. It took less than an hour and it was a positive experience. Questions were straightforward and they were genuinely interested in my previous experiences.
Interview Questions: How do you juggle requests from multiple managers? What are three attributes you would bring to this position? Describe your organizational style. What's one thing you wish had been different about your previous or current role?

title: Digital Marketing Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Aug 2021
Interview Descriptions: I submitted my application online, then was contacted shortly via email to set up a call with their HR rep, who then set me up to complete an online video-recorded interview where I recorded myself answering a few questions. After that, I got a callback to interview via Zoom with the team, then another round of Zoom with the department lead.
Interview Questions: They asked "why AHA" of course!

title: Development Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Minneapolis, MN) in Aug 2021
Interview Descriptions: First interview was a pre recorded set of questions from staff members.  Next, an interview with the recruiter. After that, the Executive Director and finally the SVP of the region.
Interview Questions: Why AHA? What are your top three qualities that would make you successful in this role? What is the biggest sale/donation you've ever secured and how? How do you handle a "no"

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Aug 2021
Interview Descriptions: I applied online, took three weeks to be interviewed, lasted 30minutes, was conducted by 2 department seniors via zoom. They were very personable and engaging, and about 2 weeks later, I was offered the position.
Interview Questions:
Why did you choose AHA?
What is your communication style?
Ask about stuff on my resume and other strengths questions.

title: Youth Market Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: Typical screening phone call, first general interview then a full on 2 hour interview. Challenging, grueling but doable! Expect to give many situational examples, show you are goal oriented and that $s matter the most.
Interview Questions:
Describe when you had to make a decision that changed a project 
Tell examples of leadership 
Examples of how many people you worked with in prior jobs or accounts managed

title: Development Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: I have just begun the interview process. I went sent a link to complete an online one way video. I must complete this in 24 to 48 hours! There are pre recorded questions.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Community Impact Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Columbia, SC)
Interview Descriptions: I was invited to complete a video introduction as part of their initial process for interviews. It was incredibly awkward and impersonal talking to a camera. Pre recorded videos of staff members at the AHA gave the questions. I did not get invited to the next round of interviews. I was very disappointed because it was a dream of mine to work there, but am glad I don't work for a company that impersonal.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work at the AHA?

title: Event Data Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: The entire process consisted of 3 interviews. The first step was online and required video responses to 5 pre-recorded questions from various people within the organization. The second was a phone interview with the direct manager. The last was a Zoom interview with the direct manager and VP over the department. Before the last interview I had to complete an online skills test, which took a little time but wasn't difficult at all. Overall the process was a little long, but well worth it in the end because it allowed both parties to make sure it's a good match. I appreciate the different steps that were taken throughout the process.
Interview Questions: Mostly I answered typical interview questions

title: Development Administrative Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Dayton, OH) in Jul 2021
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was amazing, everything was very organized and moved along quickly. They were very detailed in how the interview process was going to go and had no problem working around my than full time job to get the interviews completed.
Interview Questions: Why do you think you would do well at this role?

title: Development Director, Social Events Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Jul 2021
Interview Descriptions: First I did an interview where they gave you 4 questions and then I recorded my answers. Then, once I made it past that round I had 3 other additional zoom interviews.
Interview Questions:
-Tell me about your experience
-Give an example of a challenging work situation you experienced and how you dealt with it.
-Tell me something about you I wouldn't find on your resume.
-What made you apply for he AHA position?

title: Youth Market Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Jul 2021
Interview Descriptions:
The interview process consisted of three rounds of interviews, as follows:
First round was a video interview. 
The second round was with immediate supervisor. 
Third round was with immediate supervisor and VP.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work for AHA?

title: School Fundraising/Youth Market Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Jun 2021
Interview Descriptions: I had a total of 3 interviews. The first was just me answering prerecorded questions. I was given an opportunity to practice recording my answers and playing them back to myself before progressing on the the actual responses that would be sent to the recruiter. There was a time limit for each answer and I had about 30 seconds from the time I was given the questions until I needed to start my response. The other two interviews were over zoom. The first with my supervisor and the 2nd with my supervisor and her supervisor. Those were both more laid back and I felt at ease speaking with them.
Interview Questions: When referencing a past employer I had used as a reference, they asked how she was a good employer/mentor to me and how she might have improved.

title: Operations and Events Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Jun 2021
Interview Descriptions: I was not a fan of the digital interview and having to record myself! It seems pretty impersonal and there's no opportunity to feed on the energy of interviews. I accidentally pressed the submit button in the middle of a sentence and there goes that opportunity...
Interview Questions: What happened if and when you didn't meat a deadline?

title: Development Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Jun 2021
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was very organized and professional. The AHA recruiter was great at communicating all the details and was very helpful. All team members involved in the interview process were wonderful and made the whole experience a great one.
Interview Questions: Why would you like to work for the American Heart Association?

title: Community Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: Conversation with the recruit then led to conversation with director - General questions about background, more specific to resume rather than position, overall a fairly common interview with broad questions.
Interview Questions: what do you think american heart association does, what do you know about the organization, what drew you to this position

title: Youth Market Director Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was very easy. It started with a pre-screening phone call from HR, followed by a virtual interview with leadership and a second virtual interview with regional leadership.  The process took about two weeks total to complete and I received communication the whole time. I was also able to have a meeting with a fellow Youth Market Director to help learn more about the role and got to sit in on a planning meeting with teachers.
Interview Questions: I was asked how I feel about being told no.

title: Senior Training Consultant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Dallas, TX) in May 2021
Interview Descriptions: First you submit recorded responses through a third party interview company. This was followed by three additional interviews with the VP, then the Director of the division, and finally a group interview with the whole team. Each step of the process was about  3-4 weeks apart once the process was started.
Interview Questions: Are you able to handle frequent changes to deadlines across multiple projects?

title: Development Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association in May 2021
Interview Descriptions: Multiple virtual interviews (during COVID). First, there was a self recorded interview, followed by a couple calls from the HR team, ending with the Executive Director of the Market and an interview with the SVP of the Southeast Region.
Interview Questions:
Are you more of a "lets get it done" type of personality who wants to jump right in, or someone who takes time to analyze situations and move purposefully? You have to choose one.

How would you approach a situation where you need to make an ask quickly to reach a quarterly goal, but don't feel the relationship is far along enough yet with the donor/sponsor.

title: Development Coordnatior Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at American Heart Association in May 2021
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was rather pathetic if I'm being honest. Not only was I strung along for months but put through over 7 different interviews with 7 different employees, just to be told I wasn't selected. What confused me the most is the recruiter I was in frequent contact with kept implying I would be offered the position in a matter of days, only after my first interview. The company also struggles greatly with communication, especially those who are "Directors". How do you have the role of a "Director" but lack common communication practices?
Interview Questions: Why do you have an interest in working for a non-profit?

title: Regional Driver Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association in May 2021
Interview Descriptions: It is a very thorough interview process. The first interview was a video where I recorded my answers and submitted. This was followed by two more interviews with the Sr. Regional Director and the last was with the V.P. They were all virtual and went smoothly.
Interview Questions: What was the largest sponsorship ask I ever made.

title: Development Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association in May 2021
Interview Descriptions: There was a video record interview to begin. After that I met with the VP (Hiring Manager) for an interview to cover my experience and resume. After that I interviewed again with the VP to go more in-depth to the position and what day to day responsibilities would look like. The last interview was with the VP AND SVP to introduce us and answer some additions questions.
Interview Questions: Why AHA or Non-profit for a new position?

title: Development Director Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Tampa, FL)
Interview Descriptions: Online application, followed by a self-paced recorded interview based on five questions asked by the association. Next step, conversation with a recruiter, followed by a conversation with the managing supervisor of the role. After that, a 1.5-hour video interview with members of the Development team. The final interview was a 45-minute conversation with the Senior Vice President of the region.
Interview Questions:
Describe what your previous managers would say about you? 

What do you find to be the most difficult part of Fundraising?

title: Assistant Territory Manager Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: Went through 6 interviews just to not even be called back after my final interview they moved on with another  candidate. Biggest take away was to expect nothing and he greatful for everything. While I was crushed to not hear back I was very thankful for all the interview opportunities at this company that will better prepare me in the future for another career
Interview Questions: What do you not like about your current employer

title: Community Impact Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at American Heart Association (New York, NY) in Apr 2021
Interview Descriptions: Had a total of 5 interviews. The first was a pre-recorded one with 4 questions, which I had to record myself answering. You had one opportunity to re-record your response after each question if you wanted to. The second interview was by phone with the Recruiting Director. The third interview was with the VP of Community Impact, who the position would report to. The fourth interview was with another VP within the company. The final interview was with a VP in Development. After 3.5 weeks and 5 reference checks, they decided to go with the other candidate for the job. It's a very long process, so you need to be patient if you really want this position and hope you're the chosen one.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work for the American Heart Association?

title: Research Fellow Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: The process included two interviews. Including a phone screening and then a team interview which were all pretty approachable. The group interview was a round robin where each member asked a few questions
Interview Questions: Q: what attracted you to the American Heart Association

title: Event Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Mar 2021
Interview Descriptions: All 3 interview sessions were done virtually, in different ways, but each session was enjoyable and I appreciated the time taken each time to get to know me as a candidate! The interview processes consisted of a self-recorded video that answered questions that were pre-recorded from different AHA members, a 30-minute phone call, and a 90-minute zoom call.
Interview Questions: Q: What was a new policy or change that you contributed towards the company that is now in place?

title: Administrative Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Colorado Springs, CO)
Interview Descriptions: The process was very well thought out. The communication was very clear and I appreciated the time with everyone. It is a small office and I spoke with the HR Director and the Development Director.
Interview Questions: How do you schedule and prioritize?

title: Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: It was not a live interview (with a human) but rather a video of prompts/questions and you had a set time period to respond to them in the video (on camera).
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work here?

title: Director of Development Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Denver, CO) in Feb 2021
Interview Descriptions: I spoke to the recruiter who told me she had to speak to me. During the interview shew told me about the role and what the expectations were. She did most of the talking, only allowing me to chime in when she had a question. She gave me feedback and said she would be in contact. The whole process lasted about 45 minutes.
Interview Questions: How would I build my business to reach a donation quota of $1 million dollars.

title: Development Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Nashville, TN) in Feb 2021
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was friendly, thorough, and easy to navigate. From initial conversations with HR to speaking with local leadership, everything was great. I really enjoyed everyone that I encountered and it reaffirmed why I wanted to work with this organization.
Interview Questions: Tell us about your current experience in non-profit.

title: Community Impact Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Miami, FL) in Jan 2021
Interview Descriptions: After one week of submitting my application, I received an email with an invitation to submit a video interview. A week later,  I had a 1 hr live interview on Zoom, followed by a 30 min Zoom interview the following week.
Interview Questions: Tell me about a stressful time at work, how you handled it, and what feedback did you receive from management.

title: Healthy Heart Ambassador Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Raleigh, NC) in Jan 2021
Interview Descriptions: Very organized, and user friendly.  I had never submitted a recorded interview before.  The information that was sent about what to expect was really helpful. I was very glad that I could re-do my answers.  That helped me relax more.  The live interview was also well organized, and the questions were thought provoking.  I was also able to ask specific questions about the position that helped me decide this position is a good for for me.
Interview Questions: Describe a time when you had made a commitment, but became very busy.  How did you keep your commitment?

title: Director of Diversity and Inclusion Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Jan 2021
Interview Descriptions: My interview experience was AMAZING! The recruiter Jenny Shalifoe was the best.  Her exceptional communication really kept me in the loop throughout the entire process. The interviewing team created a very welcoming and personable atmosphere.
Interview Questions: Why did you choose AHA?

title: Communications Manager Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: Process was smooth and relatively quick. Phone screen with HR rep, phone interview and in-person interview. Team was very approachable and easy to connect with and as transparent as they could be.
Interview Questions: Specific examples of previous projects and results achieved.

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Heart Association (Salt Lake City, UT) in Dec 2020
Interview Descriptions: The interview was not very formal and laid back. I was asked many questions about my interest and what I wanted to achieve with the American Heart Association. We talked for over an hour over zoom and they were very accommodating to my needs as a student.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to collaborate with the American Heart Association?

title: Development Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Estero, FL) in Dec 2020
Interview Descriptions:
I thought the process was interesting compared to other companies I have interviewed with. My first interview was me recording myself answering 3 different questions - this was my first time experiencing something like that. My second interview was over Zoom with the Executive Director and SVP. I wasn't surprised to be meeting over Zoom, given the COVID world we're living in but I wish there was an opportunity for in person.

Prior to the second interview, I had to answer a questionnaire that felt rather long and some of the questions were semi repetitive just asked in a different way. I'm sure it's a useful tool but just felt over done.
Interview Questions: We talked a lot about my experience and what my areas of opportunity (weaknesses) are.

title: School Fundraising/Youth Market Director Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: Interviewing was a smooth and seamless process. They  communicated with me every step of the way, which helped me prepare for each interview. There was a recorded video interview, a phone call interview, and two Zoom interviews.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work for American Heart Association?

title: Senior Development Director Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Miami, FL) in Nov 2020
Interview Descriptions: I did a video interview where I had to answer some questions that was recorded and later seen by the team. I was contacted by the HR contact several times to make sure I had the support I needed and did an interview with HR. I had a 30 minute interview with the hiring managers and filled out a few self assessments. I then had a 1.5 hour interview with the hiring managers and another chat with the SVP. Very thorough process to make sure they have the right team members  in place.
Interview Questions: Three strengths and three weaknesses.

title: Vice President of Health Strategies Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Birmingham, AL) in Oct 2020
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was straightforward.   Candidates who are chosen to go through the entire process complete about three rounds of interviews.  The process is professionally led by the HR recruiter who is transparent and communicative throughout the entire process.
Interview Questions: Discuss a time when you operated in ambiguity at work/ a time when you were unsure of the outcome of the project.

title: Director of Business Development Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Oct 2020
Interview Descriptions: Submitted resume online. Received a call from the talent specialist saying they were already moving forward. Recruiter was very nice. She said that she would contact me back if there were any other openings.
Interview Questions: Did not have an interview

title: Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association (San Antonio, TX) in Oct 2020
Interview Descriptions:
Very lengthy and detailed interview process. Nearly 3 months from application to decision. Several parts:

1. Phone call with recruiter for screener interview. 
2. Online personality assessment and recorded video interview. 
3. Phone interview with hiring manager. 
4. Zoom interview with a panel of hiring manager and other potential colleagues. 
5. Phone discussion about job, request to complete online assessment and provide references. 
6. Decision + offer

Overall a very very detailed process, though it was very repetitive and did not seem to generate useful information after a while. Mostly behavioral questions or questions about my previous experience. They were very friendly and responsive to all my questions.
Interview Questions: How have you dealt with difficulties working with other people?

title: Community Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Phoenix, AZ) in Sept 2020
Interview Descriptions: The virtual recorded interview was interesting. I guess it's a way to understand who can answer on the fly.    The time between calls was a few weeks,  the structured interview process seems to be new to the interviewer.
Interview Questions: Describe a time you were able to leverage a relationship with a customer or donor?

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions:
Step1: send online application online
Step2: get email to schedule an onsite interview with hr and manager;
Step3: will get email reply from hr
the hiring process took around 4 weeks from application to hire; nice experience; many interview questions are from resume
Interview Questions: Tell me about a time when you face challenge

title: COMMUNICATIONS & MARKETING DIRECTOR Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Jacksonville, FL) in Aug 2020
Interview Descriptions:
Note: Interviews took place in the months following COVID-19 shutdowns, so all were done via phone or Zoom.

Total of 5 interviews: 1) Preset questions with timed recording of responses, covering basics/typical screening intro questions 2) Phone call with recruiter discussing position and background 3) Phone call with hiring manager discussing position and background 4) Video call with hiring manager discussing position in depth 5) Video call with regional manager - more casual discussion of job expectations and work environment, applicant personality
Interview Questions: What kind of work environment do you prefer to work in?

title: Youth Market Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Jacksonville, FL) in Aug 2020
Interview Descriptions:
Several interviews for this position.
There was a prerecorded interview where you have to record a video of yourself and submit it for your answer. Then there was a phone interview followed by a virtual interview. Final interview again was a few questions over the phone. Throughout the process there was someone to schedule each interview and ask how each interview went. Very thorough!
Interview Questions: How do you cultivate volunteers / donors?

title: Event Planner Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Boston, MA) in Aug 2020
Interview Descriptions: HR Screening went well. Interview with the person who I would be reporting to was only ok. I got the impression she was threatened by my experience. HR later told me they were pushing for me to be hired and was surprised I wasn’t.
Interview Questions: How many $100,000 donors have you secured?

title: Development Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Aug 2020
Interview Descriptions:
Strange, but welcoming
Be prepared to answer a few basic fundraising questions by recorded video response. it's short and doesn't feel authentic. but once past this step, everyone is welcoming and helpful. overall great experience.
Interview Questions: Tell me about your biggest fundraising gift received and one that fell through.

title: Corporate Development Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions:
I went through several rounds of interviews for the position with HR, the local ED, and SVP. I was emailed late on a weekday and asked to come in the next day for an in-person interview. Unfortunately, I was out of town and offered to meet virtually. I never heard back from anyone despite my attempts to follow up.

It is important to note that I applied for the same position a year prior and was told I didn't have the qualifications. When I reached out to ask what they were looking for so I could focus on professional development, they sent me a video interview and a personality test, which I completed over the weekend, only to receive the EXACT SAME letter from HR saying I didn't meet qualifications.
Interview Questions: Asked about my circle of friends including where any of my friends who were doctors worked.

title: Tech Support Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1+ week. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Arlington, TX) in Jul 2020
Interview Descriptions: At first, it was fast. I applied and the next day I was sent skill surveys and pre-screen questions. Before I even finished the survey I already got an email from the hiring manager to do an interview the next day. Since COVID-19 it's been hard to find a decent job because there is serious competition. So I'm excited to even get a ”lead”. I interviewed with the hiring manager and the director. Everyone was on time and nice. They asked me basic interview questions. What I didn't like was that they were really concerned that if my old job called me back I would leave. My problem is..that doesn't matter because I'm on an interview 4 months after being laid-off. I need a J.O.B. Then they went about asking me about equipment I would need and what they will provide for me and not to worry if I didn't have items they got it handled. In my mind, that sounds good. I sent my follow-up email, no response. Didn't really expect one. Training was set to start 10 days after I interviewed. When I reached back out it was 5 days until and still no reply. Two days later I get a no. I'm a realist. They knew it was a no before I even logged off from the virtual interview. Let's stop leaving people in limbo. The initial process was fast but the no is slow? They were hiring several people as well so I know that plays a part but just like the pandemic has changed the way we work it has also changed the way we interview.
Interview Questions: What are some of the troubleshooting techniques you would use?

title: Intern - Hourly Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Dallas, TX) in Mar 2020
Interview Descriptions: I was asked several questions about my school and prior work experience via phone. I was then asked to submit a sample writing project. Following review of my project, I had another interview and was hired.
Interview Questions: What is your prior work expeirence

title: Sales Director Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Atlanta, GA)
Interview Descriptions: Recruiter from HR call, phone screen, pre-recorded video interview, group CIDS interview (several).  The interviewers all have a packet of questions and they fill in your reply during the interview.  They let you know that there will be a few interview "sessions" as they will have to complete the book of questions.
Interview Questions: Why Heart?

title: Executive Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Dallas, TX) in Jan 2020
Interview Descriptions: Applied online, one quick 20 minute phone interview with HR, second round Skype interview with manager of job I applied for.  Skype was about 30 minutes of continuous questions with no feedback. About 20 questions about (random) skills and situations. Never asked about resume / past jobs, only situations in jobs.
Interview Questions: How do you handle sensitive information

title: Business Development Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Los Angeles, CA) in Jan 2020
Interview Descriptions: Very long interview process - one interview took 3 hours and you will  have multiple rounds of interviews with redundant questions. It might have changed recently but everything had to be in person which made it tough for scheduling
Interview Questions: What was your highschool experience like

title: Volunteer Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: Easy going, the volunteer coordinators are wonderful and truly inspired me to be a Heart Health Advocate. It was done over the phone and the initial interest I had to volunteer for the company was through email. I contacted someone from the volunteer program via email and they then followed up over the phone to confirm my interest and did a phone interview.
Interview Questions: What connection does heart health have with you personally?

title: Youth Market Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: The first interview was a screener interview with over the phone, very pleasant and conversational.  The second and third were both in-person interviews. There were a few personality tests required at each level.
Interview Questions: Tell us in your own words what you would be doing in the role you are applying for.

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: There was an initial automated phone screening, and then I was brought in for an in person interview. I interviewed with two employees. The questions were not too difficult, mostly surrounding career goals.
Interview Questions: What are your career goals?

title: Community Impact Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Baton Rouge, LA)
Interview Descriptions: Contacted by HR rep, then asked to complete video interview before speaking to hiring manager, after speaking with hiring manager in person interview with local leadership. Extensive reference check.
Interview Questions: Basic interview question...

title: Manager Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Heart Association in Oct 2019
Interview Descriptions: My experience interviewing here was definitely a career first. Time and date were confirmed for phone interview and on the day of I even did a double check with scheduler that it was still on. Received confirmation that it was a go, yet at the designated time I got no call. I called the scheduler to see if I had gotten something wrong—no answer. Sent an email—no answer. I was totally being ghosted. The following week they called to reschedule, which I reluctantly agreed to give them another chance. Should’ve trusted my gut on this one b/c when I did talk to the interviewer, she failed to apologize for missing the call and there was no recognition or regard for my time and schedule. It seemed to be ok and that they didn’t care that I had a life, schedule and other things going on.   If this is an indicator of how they treat people I’m not interested.
Interview Questions: How are you different at work than at home?

title: Administrative Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Houston, TX) in Oct 2019
Interview Descriptions: I interviewed twice. Once by video and another face-to-face. The video interview was simple enough and not very long. The in person interview was on site and very informative,
Interview Questions: Name a particular work-related achievement that you are proud of.

title: Customer Service Representative Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Dallas, TX) in Oct 2019
Interview Descriptions: Had a quick 5 min interview with someone in Human Resources before scheduling my actual interview. This interview was by phone as well. I was offered the job the same day.
Interview Questions: What customer experience do you have?

title: Management Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions:
The interview process is quite lengthy, consisting of five interviews with 6 people.   

The organization was unresponsive in providing updates, even with repeated attempts in contacting them directly and contacting multiple people in the organization.  

During this process, twice, they asked my availability for a call and I replied, only to never hear back.  

They give the appearance they are unorganized, and also are not concerned about the candidate experience.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Youth Market Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Sept 2019
Interview Descriptions: The hiring process included a phone interview. The second interview was in person with multiple staff including the hiring manager. The interviews were long and included a lot of questions. The final interview included the same staff plus the Regional Senior Vice President. The worst part was after I accepted the job but waited over 2 weeks on the background portion. I wasn't contacted regarding the wait when they said to anticipate being contacted after a couple days.
Interview Questions: How do you stay organized?

title: Youth Market Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Atlanta, GA) in Aug 2019
Interview Descriptions: My interview process was very involved because I interviewed for a high performing territory. There was an HR phone screen and then a one- way video interview. Afterwards there was a phone interview with the hiring manager and a Skype Interview with VP of Youth Markets. Then there were 2 more phone interviews with another Youth Market Director and a Youth Market Consultant.  The last interview was a quick 15 minute call from VP of Youth Markets and then an offer was extended.  I also took 3 assessments that tested my computer skills and a personality test. HR was extremely helpful throughout this entire process!!
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work for AHA?

title: Administrative Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Chicago, IL) in Aug 2019
Interview Descriptions: I had a total of 3 interviews. Everyone I met with and my HR recruiter was extremely friendly and helpful. They really make you feel at home the minute you start talking with employees.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work for the American Heart Association?

title: Director, Corporate Development Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Oklahoma City, OK) in Jul 2019
Interview Descriptions: Online application, video interview consisting of about 5 questions, phone interview with recruiter, in-person interview with would-be direct supervisor, final interview with Senior Director, Regional SVP, and Executive Director. The multi interview consisted of each person asking a question in rapid-fire style.
Interview Questions: Conflict resolution style, comfort level with calling on new clients, sales experience

title: Communication Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Denver, CO) in Jul 2019
Interview Descriptions: After an online application, if invited, you have to take a recorded video interview with yourself, and I had an essay quesstion at the end. You also have to take a personality test. I then had a phone interview with an HR rep, then an in-person interview.
Interview Questions: How would you prioritize many people asking you to do different things at the same time

title: Administrative Associate-Mid-Market Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 4 months. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Austin, TX) in Jul 2019
Interview Descriptions:
The response time was slow. I applied in April/May, then heard back a month or so later. I had to do a virtual interview where I recorded myself answering a question. I personally made a huge mistake of tripping over my words, panicking, then exiting the window hoping that it wouldn't record my response - but it still recorded it. I gathered myself and went back in and completed the remainder of the questions but they were not completed at my best level due to the feeling of 'bombing' the first question. - I got hired based on the other assessments, skills, education, etc. but I really want to discourage the use of the virtual recording interview. The experience was unpleasant and nerve-wracking because it was timed so I feel that it impaired my performance. I think that it would be helpful to have 1-3 opportunities to record and select '1' as your final answer to submit. 

There were assessments that also had to be taken which were easy to complete.
Interview Questions: Name a time where you didn't meet a deadline and what did you do.

title: School Fundraising Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Jul 2019
Interview Descriptions: About a week after I applied for the position I got an email requesting an over the phone interview. The over the phone interview took place about a week after I got the email request.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Human Resources Information Systems Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: The first round was a phone interview followed by an in-person interview. The first round was a non-technical interview where mostly the question was about the background and work experience. After that, we discussed the role.
Interview Questions: They started with my background. After that, I was asked about the projects I worked on as well as my previous work experience. Then we discussed the role and responsibilities.

title: Advisor, Foundation Relations Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 months. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: I applied in December 2018 and was told at the end of March after several follow-up attempts that I didn't get the job. The overall experience was unnecessarily long and cumbersome for a position that was not supervising anyone. First, is the recorded video interview. As someone else mentioned, it was an impersonal format and did not allow for any questions from the interviewee. I'm not sure what this accomplishes except trying to assess your improv skills. You're also harassed everyday by their automatic email system to complete it ASAP even though you're told you have a week to do it. Next, I had to provide even more information on my application online. Third came a one-hour phone interview with the hiring manager, which had many tough situational questions for a first-time "real" interview. Fourth, was a request for grant writing samples. Fifth, was in invitation for a 3-hour interview at their Baltimore office, where there was only one actual person in attendance (commuted all of the way from New Jersey to be there) and talking to a computer screen the rest of the time with the other two interviewers. All emphasized the importance of collaborating with their Mid-Atlantic program staff at the office, yet I thought it was a red flag that they did not introduce me to any of them while there or include them in the interview, especially since this was supposedly the final step in the process. In the interview, the hiring manager for the position, the Director of Foundation Relations, thought it was worthwhile to ask me what my past supervisors would say are my strengths and weaknesses are for every single job I had on my resume, including my internship from 7 years ago. I think the most off-putting question was about whether or not I did anything rectify the situation after diplomatically explaining why I left my last job (not a good fit for what I want to do) and why I'm looking for a new one. To me, you're insinuating blame on the employee rather than the employer for why you choose to leave and begging for the person to bad-mouth their past employers. Even before this interview, I had to submit five professional references, which is again, excessive. These references received a reminder email everyday until they completed their review of me, which consisted of multiple pages of questions with many asking the same thing. All of this for no offer after nearly two months of radio silence following the interview. This was hands-down the worst job interview experience I've ever had, and I would never apply to AHA again.
Interview Questions:
1. What would you say are your strengths and weaknesses?
2. What would your past supervisors say are your strengths and weaknesses?

title: Audit Data Analytics Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: Had a phone interview with 2 of the management team. Was asked questions on my resume and behavioral question. I was also asked why i wanted to volunteer with the team. Was a great interview.
Interview Questions: How familiar with you with Tableau

title: Developmental Specialist Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: Very smooth and precise interview process. They were very responsive to any questions I had about the interview process in general. I made it through 2 rounds of interviews but they decided to hire internally.
Interview Questions: What qualities do you have to offer in this role?

title: Administravie Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 days. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Tulsa, OK) in Jun 2019
Interview Descriptions: I first had a phone interview and on that interview I was told to do a video interview and some assessments. After those had been completed and reviewed I got called for an interview in the office with my supervisor and another administrative associate. The next day I had coffee with the other members of the team I would be working on. Finally  I had a one on one meeting with the executive director of the office.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work for a non-profit?

title: Communications Specialist Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: I just had a phone screening, but it seems they already had someone in mind.  Most of the questions focused around different skills I gained in college.
