Interview Questions: What skills do you have.

title: School Fundraising/Youth Market Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Tampa, FL) in May 2019
Interview Descriptions: Walked through hypothetical donor situations to see how you'd respond on your feet with real world volunteers.  Lots of "describe a time when you..." dealt with a difficult volunteer, etc types of questions.
Interview Questions: If your volunteer were to leave, how would you go about replacing them

title: Development Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association in May 2019
Interview Descriptions: I was invited to do a one-way digital interview that I found to be rather awful in terms of process and representation of a candidate. I understand the intention, but speaking into a webcam 30 seconds after reading a question and answering it within 3 minutes is a quite different interaction than having a conversation with a human about one's experience and potential fit. I also read on reviews that one is unable to redo individual questions (I believe I had 5 + 1 written), but is able to redo the entire "interview" once if needed; this was not true.
Interview Questions: What caused you to want to join AHA?

title: Administrative Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Irving, TX) in May 2019
Interview Descriptions: While the interview process was more extensive than  most, their intention is good and it was nice to feel like they also cared if the job was right for me, not just if I was right for them. I have nothing but great things to say about the entire process and the organization!
Interview Questions: How do you handle the prioritization of multiple tasks; how do you delegate with are more/less important?

title: Youth Market Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: Long process, applied online then received an e-mail from their recruiter with a link to a video interview, once that was completed there was a personality assessment, phone interview, and eventually in-person interview. Overall, it took over 2 months.
Interview Questions: What are your strengths/ weaknesses? Please provide an example of each.

title: Youth Market Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Austin, TX) in Apr 2019
Interview Descriptions: The interview process took five weeks. I received an e-mail requesting a video interview and then another e-mail from an HR coordinator for a phone screening. The following week I received a call from the hiring manager. We talked about the position, management style, my experiences etc. I then received another call from the hiring manager setting-up an in-person meeting with himself and his supervisor. The next morning, I heard from him to set-up time for a field ride-along. After that was complete the final interview was scheduled. It was a phone interview with the senior vice president of the territory. It was a smooth interview process, the hiring manager always kept me in the loop of when I would hear back.
Interview Questions: What are some of your weaknesses?

title: Youth Market Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Apr 2019
Interview Descriptions:
HR and the direct supervisor for this position were both very pleasant, responsive and timely in their responses and decisions. 

The interview process started with a video interview, a phone interview, in-person interview and a ride-along
Interview Questions: What skills do you have that will help you in this position?

title: Youth Market Director Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Apr 2019
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was very thorough. When you're applying to work at a place where you're contributing to saving lives every day, I think a thorough interview process is a MUST! I had a phone interview as well as an in person interview.
Interview Questions: If I were my last supervisor's boss, what are four pieces of advice I would give him/her to improve on?

title: Youth Market Director Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Minneapolis, MN) in Mar 2019
Interview Descriptions: I had a phone interview with someone in HR, then with the person who would be my direct supervisor. I then was given the opportunity to speak with another person on the team who had the position I was applying for, but who was in a different territory.  The final step was an in-person interview.  It was very helpful to discuss the position with a few different people to determine whether or not this was going to be a role I wanted to pursue.
Interview Questions: Tell me about a time when you had to overcome an objective.

title: Special Events Administrator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Charlotte, NC) in Mar 2019
Interview Descriptions: The interview process had many different parts and begins with a phone interview and leads up to a face to face interview. It was a positive interaction each time I spoke with someone.
Interview Questions: What previous experience do you have that will benefit you in this position?

title: Director of Business Development Heart Walk Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (San Diego, CA) in Mar 2019
Interview Descriptions: Filled out an application through a job posting. Recruiter called me 2 days after the application was filled out to setup a phone interview with the recruiter. Had a phone interview and basic introduction interview questions were asked.  Heard back from the recruiter 2 days after the call and was asked to come in for a face to face interview with the hiring manager.  Before the interview I filed out a detail application and took a 30 minute online assessment test. When I had the face to face interview the interviewer was 10 minutes late to the interview.  When I had the face to face interview questions  were all behavioral  type of questions nothing was asked about my work experience.  Interviewer seems rushed and not really interested in the interview process and wasn't very personable.  Took over a month to hear back to see if I made it to the next steps of the interviewing process.  I had to do all the follows up with them to see if I made it to the next steps and was sent an email declining me the position.  The recruiter was nice in the beginning of the process but once I had the face to face interview she dropped off the cliff on getting back to me.  Shows me her job was to get the face to face interview and then let the local AHA office to do the follow ups.  Waste of my time and money!
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work for the AHA?

title: Development Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Mar 2019
Interview Descriptions:
online application,  phone interview and video questions, skills and personality assessment then on site and in person interview 

pretty easy process  and follow up  communication , location based in TN,
Interview Questions: skills, background, familiarity with culture

title: Health Strategy Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Houston, TX) in Mar 2019
Interview Descriptions: The hiring process was fast and very organized. American Heart did a great job to be flexible on time to be able to schedule interviews. They also were very accessible if you had any question during the process.
Interview Questions: What is one thing you enjoy most from your current job and what is one thing you least like about your job?

title: Executive Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: The interview process went very smoothly. It was a multistage process made up of a phone interview and then an in-person interview. Interviewers are very nice and make you feel like part of the AHA team!
Interview Questions: They asked about past job experiences and favorite parts about previous jobs.

title: Youth Market Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Baltimore, MD) in Feb 2019
Interview Descriptions: The interview process included one phone screening and two skype interviews. The skype interviews were a new thing for me but I enjoyed them because I was able to be in the comfort of my own house. Also, the two people that I skype interviewed with were not local. For me, the interviews were more of conversations which I think is a great indication of an even better interview.
Interview Questions: Why AHA and why Youth Market Director

title: Heart Walk Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Feb 2019
Interview Descriptions: They were very straight forward about the job details and what was expected of you.  I had 4 in person interviews and 3 over the phone. They gave you a timeline and stuck to it. If you were expected to hear from them Friday by noon, you heard from them Friday by noon.
Interview Questions: In your past job, what was on thing that a company asked you to provide that was out of the normal, and how did you respond?

title: Community Advocacy Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: Brief call with recruiter, followed by an online interview. The recruiter was wonderful to speak with. The next step was the online interview which consists of a series of pre-recorded questions asked by AHA staff via video. You then have 2 minutes to record your response to the questions also via video. The format was off putting and disorienting. Each question is displayed in writing on the screen and the AHA employee is talking about their perspective and experience and then asks the interview question all while a timer is counting down, which prompts the 2 minute window for you to record your response (by video). I believe they have the staff person talk a little about themselves or the organization to make it more personal, but it's distracting while you are also reading the question and trying to ready your response before their timer expires and your timer starts. Then once the timer starts, you are basically watching yourself record an answer (which is very awkward) and have no opportunities for a re-take. While the questions were fairly straightforward, the format was impersonal and in my opinion, not the best way to evaluate how a candidate would present in person.
Interview Questions: Why are you interested in this position and why do you think you would be a good fit.

title: Development Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Jan 2019
Interview Descriptions: After submitting my resume, I was e-mailed to submit a digital interview the next day. The digital interview consisted of 5 questions that I had to record my answers to. Within two days I was contacted about coming in for an in person interview. The interview was with 3 people and lasted about an hour.
Interview Questions: Tell me about a time that you had to deal with conflict with a coworker?

title: Youth Market Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Jan 2019
Interview Descriptions: The employees at this organization made the process very streamlined.  They were very prompt when it came to contacting me about next steps.  They also helped me through the process more than any company I have interviewed with.
Interview Questions: They asked what difficulties that I had to overcome in past positions and how I was able to work through it.

title: Administrative Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Jan 2019
Interview Descriptions: The digital interview and phone interview are scheduled first. If the phone interview is successful, the applicant moves on to the in-person interview with the hiring manager. The phone interview serves as a screening method to identify those who would most likely be hired.
Interview Questions: They asked about a situation involving conflicting priorities and how they were handled.

title: Development Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Dallas, TX) in Jan 2019
Interview Descriptions: Pretty standard. Two rounds of interviews with Development Directors and VP of Development. Standard  questions that were focused on organizational skills, administrative support or event focused.  I would recommend the interview process.
Interview Questions: What is your why as it related to the mission?

title: Heart Walk Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: After applying I received a call from an HR recruiter...after a typical call with many generic interview screening questions I didn't have to wait long to meet with the Heart Walk leadership. This is where I really learned more about the job I applied for. The screening interview didn't provide me the clearest picture of the position but the in-person interview helped paint a clear picture of the role, responsibility and culture. Luckily I was called back in a week later for another call/in-person and before I was able to get back home I had received by first offer.  6 weeks in so far so good...come ready to hustle and sale. Thankfully for me I was able to get to work ASAP.
Interview Questions: Phone interview was very basic out of the packet questions...mostly about previous experience and relevant skills

title: Policy Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Dallas, TX) in Dec 2018
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was normal and competitive. Most of the questions that were asked were regarding my past experiences with the organization when I partnered with them.  I had to complete a project as well as go through the interview process.
Interview Questions: Q: Which past experiences would most benefit you in this position? Which past experience will not add to the position?

title: Community Impact Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Glen Allen, VA) in Dec 2018
Interview Descriptions: Candidate was required to conduct a virtual interview and attend to interviews.  Candidate had to take a microsoft skills assessment test which was challenging if you do not use specific tasks on a daily basis.
Interview Questions: How would you prepare for the position/your work?

title: Youth Market Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Riverside, CA) in Nov 2018
Interview Descriptions: Skype Interview with division director along with youth market director there in person; both people were very kind and patient. It was a very comfortable interview! It lasted about 30-45 minutes I'd say and they got back to me within 2 days afterward offering me the position.
Interview Questions: Do you feel uncomfortable asking for money?

title: Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Dallas, TX)
Interview Descriptions: The first step required a 6 question Video interview. A couple days later I was called and screened by the HR department. A week later I had a Face to face interview. The following week I was asked to come in the office for a Panel interview.
Interview Questions: Describe a time you have been innovative in your work.

title: Development Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Tulsa, OK) in Oct 2018
Interview Descriptions: The initial process was a little long/slow to start.  I fist did a phone interview.  Then I was invited to do an online assessment and video interview. . . the actual questions were very job specific and nothing at all like the generic practice questions. After that I went in for an initial in person interview with 2 department heads.  Then, finally I met with My Executive director for another interview.  About a week later, I was told I was hired.  The hard part was the time in between tasks and the whole, "not knowing" aspect.  Every interaction however was pleasant and positive.
Interview Questions: The questions asked were pretty typical . . . name something that youve had to overcome/how/why/what was the outcome.  One question that did slip me up though was "tell me about a time when you had a lapse in judgement" I did not have a prepared answer but feel confident I handled it okay.

title: Vice President-Health Strategies Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Arlington, VA) in Oct 2018
Interview Descriptions: It was very comprehensive, thorough and engaging! It is one of the most detail oriented interview processes I have ever been though in my entire career. I was particularly impressed with the HR Representative shepherding the process. She was kind, detailed oriented and moved the process along very well with gentle reminders if a step was delayed. She consistently asked whether I had any questions. I enjoyed the four panel final interview the most when I got to meet the entire leadership team I will be engaging with and had the opportunity to ask them my questions for 30 minutes.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work for the American Heart Association?

title: Communications Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Des Moines, IA) in Sept 2018
Interview Descriptions: The first interview was a video interview. The interviewee has a set amount of time to answer the question and can only do it once. Next there was an additional application and an ACCESS Personality Survey to fill out prior to the in person interview. The survey is pretty long and takes a while to get through. Then the in person interview followed up with a phone interview.
Interview Questions: What would be the first thing you want to implement in this role?

title: Development Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: AHA offered a very thorough interview process with a lot of ease, which moved very quickly (three weeks between application submission and receiving offer). I was originally contacted by a recruitment director for an initial screening interview, and on that phone call I was asked to move forward to a recorded video interview. That same day that I submitted my video recording, I was invited to an in-person interview, and after one final phone call with a senior staff member, was made an offer. All questions were basic but thought-provoking, and mostly based on my prior college interests/background and work experience.
Interview Questions: What is one critique you have of your former supervisor?

title: Project Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Dallas, TX) in Aug 2018
Interview Descriptions: Brief phone interview followed by an in-person interview, both with team leader. The process was a little tricky, since they were restructuring the team and couldn't always give specific answers to questions that might have helpful in speaking to how you could contribute to their projects. Heard back that they went with someone else from someone I hadn't ever spoken to via an automated email.
Interview Questions: What's been your proudest professional accomplishment?

title: Director of Development Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Aug 2018
Interview Descriptions: Started with a phone screen and then a video interview where you are asked varied questions on camera. After that you go into the branch office for the face to face interviews. If you make it past there you have a Skype call with the Regional director.
Interview Questions: Why the AHA?

title: High Level Position Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: I made it through several phone interviews and then had a phone interview with an executive. Once she realized that I lacked a certain qualification, she cut the interview short. I never heard back from anyone despite emailing and calling. Very unprofessional for such a large organization.
Interview Questions: Tell me about your career

title: Development Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: Very long process. Screening interview, second screening interview with HR, video recording where answers appear on the screen and you record yourself answering them, and finally an in person interview that lasts 2+ hours with several people from the office
Interview Questions: What tasks do you tend to procrastinate?

title: Finance Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Dallas, TX) in Jul 2018
Interview Descriptions:
There was a phone interview and then an in person interview.  
The in person interview was a panel with the hiring manager coming in for the last 5 minutes.  Very unprofessional.
Interview Questions: They asked how I would handle priorities.

title: Communications Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 8 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: Interview process began with a bizarre video interview, having me answer questions appearing on my screen that were then recorded.  Then, there was a 1/2 hour interview with hiring manager. Why so short after having to take a day off of work was beyond me. Lastly, there was a panel of interviewers. Nice people, but they all had scripted questions they didn't ever veer from. I'm sure the questions were a directive from AHA. In my opinion, not the best way to get to know a candidate. Then, they required 5 references, as if I was applying for some sort of high-security governmental position. In the end, left feeling uneasy about the organization, which was why I wasn't too upset that i didn't get an offer.
Interview Questions: All questions asked were incredibly scripted; Explain a time you handled conflicting opinions at work.

title: Special Events Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: They have a separate HR Department for each region. The HR director reaches out, does a phone screen and then sends 2 rounds of online surveys. Personally, I then had 2 separate in person interviews.
Interview Questions: What past experience do you have in fundraising?

title: Associate Managing Editor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Boston, MA) in May 2018
Interview Descriptions:
-phone screen
-video recorded interview
-online application (in addition to initial application)
-in-person interview

I felt this application and screening process was a bit time-consuming, especially when it became clear in the interview they were not interested in moving forward. AHA makes you jump through a lot of hoops and it may not be worth it in the end.
Interview Questions: Describe a challenging situation and how you overcame it

title: Area Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Huntsville, AL) in May 2018
Interview Descriptions: It was an in person interview with the immediate supervisor and a Vice President.. It didn’t seem like a high pressure interview. The company is a respectable one with a great reputation. I think I needed more direct sales experience to gain an offer. It was a good learning experience.
Interview Questions: Name a time I failed in my career and what did I learn from it.

title: Development Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Okemos, MI) in May 2018
Interview Descriptions: I applied online and heard back a few days later from the HR Recruiter.  We scheduled a 30 minute phone screen.  I was asked to do a personality test and give a couple of references. My second round interview was in person with the Regional Vice President and another Director. I was advanced to the final round about a week after and had another in person interview with the SVP included and was offered later that day. The process was quick and communication was great throughout the whole thing!
Interview Questions: Why the American Heart Association?

title: Development Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association in May 2018
Interview Descriptions: The total interview process took a little over a month. All communication was done through an HR rep from corporate. It started with a phone screen with HR and then I was sent a link to a video interview. After I completed the video interview, I didn't hear anything for a couple weeks. Then I received a call from HR and we set up a time for me to have an in person interview.
Interview Questions: Rate your proficiency in Microsoft Office - specifically excel, word, powerpoint, and outlook.

title: Communications and Digital Strategies Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Philadelphia, PA) in May 2018
Interview Descriptions: Five interviews, two skills tests, and a personality assessment.  The interview process was rigorous but more-or-less smooth. Passionate, smart people at the organization. I was offered the job, negotiated a few things (i.e. salary, start date), and accepted the revised offer. I signed and submitted the revised offer letter and sign-on bonus. HOWEVER, they then suddenly rescinded the offer! I was told that the person currently holding the role (and set to leave to start her own business) had a change of heart and asked to keep her job. They had my signed offer letter in their inbox! The recruiter said that everyone was very impressed with me and that they'd keep me in mind for another position at the organization, but nothing came to fruition. I understand that this was a unique circumstance but very unprofessional outcome and left a bad taste in my mouth. Is a shame because it seems like an otherwise great organization.
Interview Questions: Typical interview questions e.g., tell us about a successful campaign, a challenging situation, etc.

title: Customer Service Representative Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Richardson, TX) in May 2018
Interview Descriptions: Longer interview process than expected for a position like this. Didn't receive a call back until almost a month and half after application date. Brief 10 minute phone interview with supervisor, then a video interview with a set of 6 questions and 2 minutes to film yourself answering those questions, and lastly an in-person interview with supervisor and higher up. There was a skills test after the in person interview.
Interview Questions: What is your favorite and least favorite technology?

title: Go Red Director Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Birmingham, AL) in Apr 2018
Interview Descriptions:
The interview Process went rather quickly based on other experiences - applied on March 30 and received an offer May 4. 

The recruiter was phenomenal! She was very personal and responsive. I had already had a phone screening with her, completed an online interview and spoke via phone with the local VP (The ED was out). While I did not receive an offer for that position, I applied for the Go Red Director which became open a few months later. I received a call from the recruiter to schedule an in person interview with the local ED. Next I completed a personality test - theirs was pretty lengthy with 350+ questions (I, personally, find these incredibly hard). Then I had a Skype interview with the ED and the person promoted out of the available position. I received the offer the next day.

The online interview was pretty advance, with maybe 10 question which you recorded yourself responding. You were able to practice, but once you started the actual interview you could not review each question. You either had to scrap the whole thing or start fresh (only 2 chances total). I chose to stick with my first attempt.

They worked with me in regards to the fact I was not local - I live in another State.  While their interview process has many, many steps, it  moved rather quickly. With all of the different phases, I never felt like I was anxiously waiting around and it made that month go by quickly.
Interview Questions: Tell me about a time a volunteer had an idea that didn't quite align with your organizations views. How did you handle the situation?

title: Administrative Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Eagan, MN) in Apr 2018
Interview Descriptions: The interview process is very thorough but in a great way!  It's obvious that the American Heart Association takes pride in who they hire for each and every position.
Interview Questions: One example of an interview question I had was "How do you learn best?" referring to training and onboarding for the position.

title: Development Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Milwaukee, WI) in Apr 2018
Interview Descriptions: Spoke with their recruiter, filled out application online, filled out persona assessment online, then spoke with manager on phone.  Met for an in-person interview with manager and someone from upper management. Received call with offer later that week from recruiter.
Interview Questions: What would you do if a volunteer was not following through with their commitment?

title: Intern Marketing Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (New Brunswick, NJ)
Interview Descriptions: I applied online and then had two phone interviews. The interviews were with the same person each time, but the second one was much more in depth. I got an offer shortly after the second phone call.
Interview Questions: Tell me about your experience

title: Administrative Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Canton, OH) in Mar 2018
Interview Descriptions: I had a phone screen with HR.  Then an interview with the director I would be working with.  The whole interview was very off-putting.  I would be asked some questions 3 different times during the interview, almost as if she was trying to get me to change my answers or see if I was really being honest? It was very strange.  She had a very condescending tone that after any question I answered no matter what I said I was made to feel like an idiot.  Once the interview was over I knew I wouldn't enjoy the job.
Interview Questions: Behavioral based

title: Development Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Mar 2018
Interview Descriptions: There was a brief phone call, followed by an intense 2.5 hour panel interview with 3+ members of the team and executive director. It was very thorough, as it seems that they do their due diligence when hiring. I was offered the position, but the salary I was promised in the beginning was not what they ended up offering. It seemed like a "bait-and-switch" situation and I've heard that it has happened there before.
Interview Questions: What is one thing you failed at in college?

title: Director of Development Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Columbus, OH) in Mar 2018
Interview Descriptions: There was a process of three interviews. The initial phone interview led to an interview done by the applicant in which you record answers to questions you are given on the spot. After completion of that, I was invited to a third and final interview. Due to me not living in the same city as the position, they scheduled for me to meet at a local AHA office for a Skype interview with direct Supervisors. It was a very clear and concise interview process which included great communication along the way from multiple parties.
Interview Questions: How did you respond to adversity when it came from someone you supervise or someone that supervises you  (And what was the specific example).

title: Development Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Mar 2018
Interview Descriptions: I applied online and was asked to do a video interview where I would be prompted with the question and given a couple of minutes to answer. It was different and a little awkward.
Interview Questions: Why would you like to work for the American Heart Association?

title: Internship Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association (New York, NY)
Interview Descriptions: The interview was pretty basic we went over past experience. Passions and career goals. Basic interview questions strength and weaknesses etc. the interview was given by two employees at the same time
Interview Questions: Biggest strength

title: Program Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Palm Beach, FL) in Feb 2018
Interview Descriptions: Three different interviews, one with HR, one on the computer on a webcam, final with individuals.  While I liked their extensive interview process, once I got in person, I was met with the rudest people ever.  By the time I left, I was so over the interview, I knew I would never accept a position from them.  The feeling was probably mutual since I did not get an offer, but it made me never want to work for this company which is not a good way to do business.
Interview Questions: What was something you would not repeat?

title: Administrative Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Canton, OH) in Feb 2018
Interview Descriptions: First a phone interview with a corporate HR person, and then I received an email from an administrative assistant asking to set up a phone interview with the Director of Advancement.  The day came for the call, I made arrangements to leave work early to take the call, and the time for the call came and went.  No call, no email about rescheduling, apologizing, nothing.  Later that evening, I sent an email to the Admin asking if it was going to be rescheduled, and received a reply the next day asking if I could do it that day.  Again, left work early to be able to take the call.  The person who called and interviewed me was SO CONDESCENDING.  I have extensive volunteer leadership experience, and she kept repeating how different a "large nonprofit that is run like a corporation" is from what I am used to.  Okay, maybe, but I also have a degree in Organization Administration and I wouldn't have applied if I didn't think I could handle it.  When it came time for me to ask any questions I had, I said that while I am familiar with their 4 events per year, I admittedly do not know where they fall on the calendar, and could she explain a bit more what activities the job entails that make it a full time job.  Her response:  "WOOOWWWWWWWWWWWWWW!  Okay then!!!!"  Then she rattled off a list of things like "entering auction items", etc., asked if I had any more questions, and when I said, "No, I think that is it", she basically cut me off, said, "Okay, well thanks", and hung up on me.
Interview Questions: When was a time when you realized you were not a cultural fit for something?

title: Technology Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Dallas, TX) in Feb 2018
Interview Descriptions: After initial application, I was contacted for an in-person interview. The interview only took about an hour, after which they emailed me an offer. After accepting the offer, it took less than a week to set up my start date.
Interview Questions: Are you familiar with Windows 10?

title: Management Interview Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Houston, TX) in Feb 2018
Interview Descriptions: I applied online and was contacted by Human Resource.  In total, I had 5+ interviews for a Sr. Management role.  As I progressed, I was encouraged. However, in the final interview stage, I engaged with a new interviewer who could be my peer.  She kept my presentation, but we did not connect. I felt this was unprofessional and realized this job and organization were not for me.
Interview Questions: Tell me about your experience.

title: Director of Development Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Washington, DC) in Jan 2018
Interview Descriptions: Applied online and was contacted by talent recruiter the next day. Scheduled a 30 minute phone screen with the recruiter a week later. Followed up with a one hour interview with the Executive Director and VP of Development.
Interview Questions: Walk us through your resume.

title: Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Raleigh, NC) in Jan 2018
Interview Descriptions: Poorly Organized, Hiring manager asked irrelevant questions, the other interviewer did not pay attention and was sleeping throughout the process so I just got up and left. I really was not happy with the whole process.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Customer Service Representative Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Dallas, TX) in Dec 2017
Interview Descriptions: About an hour long,  average interview questions, very friendly and conversational interview I was introduced to several people and gave me a tour to the building, after the interview I did an assessment test and a week later received the offer letter.
Interview Questions: Tell us about your working experience,

title: Administrative Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions:
I would like to preface my review by saying that everyone I corresponded with was extremely nice and great! Any issues I had with the process were a result of the centralized interview structure and not the people involved. 

Essentially, this interview seemed way too intense for an entry level job. By the end of the process, there were four separate parts- a recorded video interview, a phone interview, an in person interview, and a final in person interview. I think this whole process can be streamlined.  They are asking people to take at least two days off of work at times for a job that they may or may not get. The final interview was over two hours and consisted of very canned questions that became redundant. The questions are the same for every job at this organization- that doesn't seem efficient because every role is different.  I think AHA needs to be more considerate of the time off people have to take and maybe consider making the final interview only for the top contender. 

I think the process needs to be more personalized.
Interview Questions:
Name a time when....
Would you rather ask permission or forgiveness?
Describe a time you completed a project.
Describe a time you completed a project with multiple components. 
Very redundant questions. I was repeating myself because the questions were so similar.

title: Health Strategies Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: First I did a video interview where I recorded my answers. Then I completed some online tests.  Afterwards, I was interviewed in person by 3 individuals who I would be directly supporting!
Interview Questions: Tell us about a time you had a problem arise at work and how did you respond?

title: Director Interview
Application Type: The process took 2+ months. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: Its a 4-7 step interview that can take anywhere from 2 weeks to 3 months to actually start.  Phone interview, video interview, assessments, interview with supervisor, interview with all upper management.
Interview Questions: Why are you looking to leave or why did you leave your last position?

title: Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Fort Worth, TX)
Interview Descriptions: Very thorough process. The process consisted of a video interview, 1st interview, assessment, and then a final interview. Took a long time but felt I really earned it in the end!
Interview Questions: What do you know about AHA?

title: Community Impact Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Oct 2017
Interview Descriptions: Quick response, first round is a video pre screen, the questions are sent to you and you record them, as well as a personality assessment. If you pass that, you move on.
Interview Questions: What does personal accountability mean to you?

title: Vice President, Regional Sales Management Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Austin, TX) in Oct 2017
Interview Descriptions: It started with a telephone interview, and progressed to a video interview and personality profile.  The video interview was virtual.  There was not an actual other person involved.
Interview Questions: Experience in fundraising

title: Senior Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Houston, TX) in Oct 2017
Interview Descriptions: Phone screen, one way video interview, personality assessment, Skype video interviews, in person interview with hiring manager and final interview with senior leadership team. Was asked to present a talent acquisition process on a hard to fill position.
Interview Questions: Walk us through how you would hire for a hard to fill senior position?

title: Director of Government Relations Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Albany, NY) in Sept 2017
Interview Descriptions:
Email screening, followed by on-line interview recording, then in-person interview. This last was very professional and focused. No complaints about the process (though if you were to use the on-line app on your Mac, you'd have to use Flash, so they need to modernize that). 

AHA seems very organized and by-the-book. Gave the impression of being an ok place to work.
Interview Questions: Give an example of an occasion where you advocated for a cause.

title: Development Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Okemos, MI) in Sept 2017
Interview Descriptions: I first applied online.  About 2 weeks later I received a call about completing a video interview. The third stage of the process was an in person interview and the final stage was an additional video interview.
Interview Questions: How would your former manager describe you?

title: Event Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Syracuse, NY)
Interview Descriptions: After submitting my resume online, I received a call from HR who then made an appointment for me to meet with my now direct supervisor.  In about a week, I then met with the team I now work with for a second interview.  I received a phone call from HR around a few days and was offered the position based on a background check.  I filled out the paperwork to have the background check done and was hired.  The entire process took about a month from start to finish.  It shows me that they really care about who they hire and if they are the right fit for the team.
Interview Questions: My experiences and how they would play a role in my current position.

title: Project Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Dallas, TX) in Aug 2017
Interview Descriptions:
The first interview was over the phone with HR. It was basically to see if I was the right candidate for the program. We discussed qualifications based on my resume and was asked to expand on my experience. 

The second interview was a panel of 2. We discussed my experience again and I provided details and examples. I was also asked about 5 situational questions to see how I would handle any problems that my come with the positon. 

Might I add, the interviewers were not intimidating at all. They were very warm and smiled the entire time so I felt comfortable. They made it a point to make the process feel more like a conversation and less like an interview which I really appreciated.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Health Consultant Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 4 months. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Dallas, TX) in Aug 2017
Interview Descriptions:
1. There was an initial phone screen with the hiring manager.
2. An in-person interview was conducted with the hiring manager and her supervisor.
3. A virtual interview was conducted with two members of the team.

There were long periods of time between the interviews.  After the final interview, there was approximately a one month delay before an offer was made.
Interview Questions: If you were going to introduce a new concept to a "field or market" how would you go about doing it?

title: Data Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Dallas, TX) in Aug 2017
Interview Descriptions: Process is smooth and not much technical questions were asked. The process took 4 weeks. the managers are really nice and the overall experience are good. It was a good interview experience for sure.
Interview Questions: Why AHA?

title: Administrative Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Okemos, MI) in Aug 2017
Interview Descriptions: The beginning of my interview process started with a video interview where you would be given questions and then you had to record yourselves giving your response. From there I was contacted for an in-person interview where I spoke with the directors who were doing the actual hiring. It was a very welcoming environment and I left the interview even more interested in the company than when I arrived because of how highly the directors talked about AHA. From there I had a phone interview with someone from another department and a follow up interview in person again where I met the other Administrative Assistants in the office, which was again very welcoming and friendly. I was then contacted by HR a few days later with my offer. Overall, such a great experience.
Interview Questions: Aside from the usual past relevant work experience questions, one question I thought was particularly cool was that they asked me aside from the department I was applying to work for, what other areas I was interested in gaining experience in.

title: Council Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 4 days. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Dallas, TX) in Aug 2017
Interview Descriptions: I was asked questions about my job role now. How do I contribute to my team in advancing and reaching our goals. What are my strengths and weaknesses. And how would I handle certain situations in the work place.
Interview Questions: How does my role contribute to my team?

title: Development/Event Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Baton Rouge, LA) in Aug 2017
Interview Descriptions:
The selection process began with a phone screen from the HR department in Florida. The phone screen was fairly easy because I have all of the qualifications necessary to be successful in the position. They just asked generic things like, "What's the largest event you've worked on?", "Do you have event planning/fundraising experience?" 

I passed the phone screen. I was invited to do a video interview later that evening with an online software. I can't remember the name of it. The video screen was only five questions. 

I passed the video screen and got invited to an in-person interview. It took about a week to get a formal invitation.I also had to do a personality assessment and gather five references. The in-person interview went well. However, I found the hiring managers to be a bit duplicitous. They were almost too nice. 

My assumption was right. I was gassed as if I was a shoe-in to get the position. I emailed a thank you after the interview and was met with an overwhelmingly pleasant response. Again, I was gassed as if I was the chosen candidate. It took about two weeks to finally get a declining phone call from the region's VP.
Interview Questions: What do you do in order to maintain relationships and solicit donations for events?

title: Social Market Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Tucson, AZ) in Aug 2017
Interview Descriptions: Very friendly staff that made you feel comfortable throughout the whole interview.  The interview was about 15 minutes long. They asked basic questions tailored to the specific position.
Interview Questions: What do you know about the American Heart Association?

title: Executive Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: Online application followed by one way video interview which consisted of screening questions that would normally be asked in a phone screening. Followed up two weeks later to ask where they were in the process. Shortly after, received an invitation for an in person interview.  The hiring manager was very direct and stated during the interview that the position included additional responsibilities not included in the job description. It was clear that due to budgetary constraints, the hiring manager was combining multiple positions under the title Executive Assistant. They reviewed my resume and began asking questions  about professional experience on my resume that I felt would typically be unrelated to such a position. They were candid about their needs, offered no information about what AHA would offer a new employee. They left very little time for any questions I might have and let me know they had limited time. Additionally, they mentioned a few personal frustrations they had concerning the company. I thought that was unprofessional. It ended abruptly and I was told they would be making a decision quickly. This was a very long process for a misrepresented position. This is very disrespectful to job applicants.
Interview Questions: What do you think this job is about?

title: National Marketing Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Dallas, TX) in Jul 2017
Interview Descriptions:
The interview process was fairly challenging, but I appreciate the organization's commitment to hiring qualified individuals. The process was as follows:
1) Video interview. The AHA sent a link to complete an online, video recorded interview. This was the most stressful part of the entire process for me. You're given 20-40 seconds to read a question before the recording portion begins. Once your timer starts, you have a set number of minutes you can use to answer the question(s) asked. I believe there were 8-10 in total, and they were not your typical "initial interview/phone screen" questions. They dove deep into my experience, my past project management skills, they asked for specific examples of past work completed, etc. You cannot go back and watch your recordings, but if you feel you did poorly, they give you the chance to do the entire interview again. You, however, may not go back to specific questions and re-record those individually. The entire interview has to be completed again.
2) Phone interview with my hiring manger. This was very similar to a one-on-one in-person interview, just done over the phone.\
3) In-Person panel interview.  Four AHA staff members were in the room, and it was a round robin discussion.
4) Offer letter.
Interview Questions: Discuss how you prioritize tasks when you have multiple projects due in a short amount of time. What steps did you take to ensure everything was completed? How do did you plan schedules around it? Give examples from your previous experience.

title: Event Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Jacksonville, FL) in Jul 2017
Interview Descriptions: A few weeks after applying for the job I received an email from  HR. The email said "it was a pleasure speaking to you on the phone today..." followed by instructions on how to do the video/online interview. I was never phoned by HR. So I found this confusing and it took me several days to get in touch with her to figure out what was going on. She apologized for never actually calling me and just sending the email and asked me to move forward with the online video interview. After completing that I was contacted for a phone interview with her which I completed. Then she asked me to do a phone interview with the hiring manager. After that was completed she called me and said that they thought I was a "rock star" and wanted to move forward with the final in person interview with a panel of people. She said they were "so confident with wanting to hire me that they wanted me to do an online personality assessment and complete a more detailed application to include references." This online assessment and the time it took for me to include many more details into my online application took me approximately 3 hours of time to complete. I then went in for my in person interview which went very well and took about two hours. I was told by both HR and the hiring panel that I would be notified the following week on moving forward. The following week I heard nothing. I reached out to HR once mid-week and left a vm asking where they were in the hiring process. She never returned my call. The next week I reached out again and left ANOTHER vm for. She did not return my call. Since I was holding off on making some future plans and commitments because I had been given a very strong indication from HR that they would be making me an offer... I tried calling a third time using a blocked caller ID. MY HR recruiter picked up the phone on the second ring and once I identified myself she acted like she had no idea who I was. After she did realize who I was, she said the position has been filled and she sent me an email that I did not receive the position. After triple checking my email, I will verify, that I NEVER received an email from HR or anyone else at the AHA telling me I did not get the position. I am very dissatisfied with the interview process since I took over 10 hours of my personal time to complete all the different interviews and steps. Was led to believe on several occasions from HR that I would be offered the job. And then, no one had the consideration to even call me to tell me that I did not get the position or give me any explanation or reason why. I feel like when someone goes this far in the interview process and it is only down to a few people, AHA should at least have the consideration to call that person... not claim they sent and email which was never sent. The job search process can be very stressful and being in the dark for 2 weeks after my final interview left me with many sleepless nights followed by much frustration when HR would not even return my phone calls.
Interview Questions: All of the questions were example based of past professional experiences. Very standard.

title: Project Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: Remote location recruiter contacts prospects by e-mail . A first phone interview is scheduled, which was honored and on time. After this, a second phone interview was to happen, however, it was never communicated or followed through.  Closure is always nice
Interview Questions: Describe your current job and  are your responsibilities. Conversation was very fluid, not your typical canned interview, which was refreshing.

title: Youth Market Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Jul 2017
Interview Descriptions: Very smooth, transparent, quick, and efficient process. 4 steps...1)phone interview with HR rep from diff location 2) phone interview with direct supervisor 3) in person interview with direct supervisor 4) in person interview with direct supervisor, SR VP, and top team member.  Process was completed within 2 weeks following first phone interview due to desire to hire immediately for right candidate.
Interview Questions: Doing a role play

title: Digital Operations Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 4 months. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Dallas, TX) in Jul 2017
Interview Descriptions: The Interview and Hiring process was longer than most, but the process was efficient and the support from the recruiter was exemplary from first contact to onboarding. The process was longer only because of the logistics of interviewing with a hiring manager who travels frequently.
Interview Questions: How do you see yourself as a contributor to AHA?

title: Youth Market Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Valdosta, GA) in Jun 2017
Interview Descriptions: I was called for a screening interview, then completed a video interview, and then completed an in-person interview.  The video interview required web camera capability and a software download.  Additionally, the date of the face to face was rescheduled for staff convenience.
Interview Questions: I was asked how I handled  a challenging work situation.

title: Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Los Angeles, CA) in Jun 2017
Interview Descriptions: It was a standard interview. I applied online and was invited to submit a video interview. The video interview consisted of five questions where I had 2-3 minutes to provide a response. I was then invited for an in person interview with one of the directors. Questions asked included about my past professional experiences and responsibilities and how they relate to the current job posting responsibilities.
Interview Questions: Why are you interested in working for the company? What conflict have you dealt with at work and how did you overcome the challenge.

title: Director of Development Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at American Heart Association (San Diego, CA) in May 2017
Interview Descriptions: Very slow turn around time. Took over two weeks to schedule an interview and 8 weeks to let me know that I was not moving forward to the next stage of the process.
Interview Questions: Have you managed a team of volunteers?

title: Business Development Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Oakland, CA) in May 2017
Interview Descriptions: Applied online through the AHA website- took about two days to hear back for an interview. I also applied to other location positions and didn't hear that I hadn't gotten an interview for a while. There was a phone interview, an in person interview, and a CIDS in person interview
Interview Questions: What motivates you when tasks are somewhat monotonous?

title: Administatve Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association in May 2017
Interview Descriptions: Submitted resume.  Received call from corporate headquarters (not in the state I would be working).  Told resume looked great but needed to do a one-way video interview.  Extremely impersonal.   Rather surprised that they narrowed the field this way.  Quite a bit of a job is if you mesh with the team.   Not interviewing with the team was a disappointment.  Most skills can be taught - but if your personality is not a fit all the skills in the world will not help.  Have not heard back so not expecting it to more forward.
Interview Questions: What I thought the position exactly was.

title: Program Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Dallas, TX) in May 2017
Interview Descriptions: Phone call with recruiter followed by Skype. General questions about work history and working style. In-person interview with management was more in depth and involved answering questions about managing projects and skill sets. Also emotional intelligence.

title: Data Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Dallas, TX) in Apr 2017
Interview Descriptions: The position is the data analyst. Three phases included. First, an initial phone screen, last for 15 min. Then there are two following on-site interview, one lasts 1 hour and another one last for one and a half hour. Many behavior questions in the on-site interview.
Interview Questions:
How to make sure the data in the report is correct? 
How to deal with the conflicts with colleagues?

title: Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Dubai) in Apr 2017
Interview Descriptions: I did an interview 15 working days ago, it was very positive. i have a query, how long does it take to get the feedback, As i am still waiting ?
Interview Questions: I did an interview 15 working days ago, it was very positive. i have a query, how long does it take to get the feedback, As i am still waiting ?

title: Youth Market Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Wallingford, CT) in Apr 2017
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was very quick.  Once resume was submitted I then received an email for a video interview.  After submitting my video interview the one on one process began.
Interview Questions: How do you handle failure and what did you learn?

title: Development Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Wichita, KS) in Apr 2017
Interview Descriptions: Went into local office and met with a person from out of town. She did not seem to have a good handle on the local office and her standards were much higher than what I saw after being hired.

title: Socials Consultant Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Chicago, IL) in Apr 2017
Interview Descriptions: An internal recruiter made the initial outreach and then hosted a phone interview.   From there, I then had a phone  interview with the hiring manager and a few weeks later, the hiring manager travelled to Chicago to meet me for an in-person interview with one of his peers.
Interview Questions: They asked me many questions, but one that surprised me was; "What bugs you/gets under your skin at work?"

title: Director of Development Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Apr 2017
Interview Descriptions: The interview and hiring process were seamless. The entire process took 3 weeks from start to offer.  There was an initial phone screen, then a 1:1 interview with supervisor, followed by and interview with supervisor and regional VP.
Interview Questions: How do you handle pacing goals and benchmarks?

title: Health Strategies Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Arlington, VA)
Interview Descriptions: Two interviews: one phone interview and one in person with other members of the department. The interviews were straightforward and pleasant, the whole process took about a month. They require a background check.
Interview Questions: Are you a team player?

title: Policy Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Apr 2017
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was a pleasant experience. In dept questions  regarding your experience are asked, therefore, it is a must that you be thoroughly prepared. They do cover the costs of travel.
Interview Questions: What qualities would you bring to the role? How has your previous experienced prepared you for this role?

title: Project Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: The process started with a phone interview, then I was called in for an in-person interview. After that, i had an additional phone interview with some of the people I would be supporting. After all those steps, i completed a skills test (Microsoft Office- Word, Excel, Outlook) prior to the offer being made. Note- HR called with the offer, not the hiring department.
Interview Questions: Tell us about a time when you had to solve a difficult problem with others you worked with.

title: Youth Market Director Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was long and it was a three part interview that included a field ride. One part of the interview was on video, another part was over the phone, the last part consisted of a field ride with a fellow director. My boss resided in another state, so I think the interview process was a bit different for me. great interview process
Interview Questions: Would you rather ask for permission or forgiveness?

title: Director of Development Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Charleston, SC) in Feb 2017
Interview Descriptions: Completed and submitted an application online, received a phone call from HR, completed and submitted a video interview.  Not a lengthly process as others describe since it was cut short from HR.  The ground level has absolutely no say so in the hiring process.  Candidates are selected from corporate and then presented to the field managers.
Interview Questions: What is your direct fundraising experience?  Describe the number of people, coordination of the event, and results.

title: Development Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Boston, MA) in Feb 2017
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was a two step interview process, the first was with the VP of the department, and the second was with multiple members of the department along with the VP. I was asked many situational questions, and questions to describe experiences of my past work experiences and how I handled them.
Interview Questions: What my ideal work position was, if I could have any position I desired.

title: Fundraising Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (New York, NY) in Jan 2017
Interview Descriptions: Phone interview and then two face to face. One with hiring manager and one with hiring manager, ed and SVP. Usual interview. No unexpected questions - "tell me a time when..." format
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Sales/Fundraising HeartChase Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Jan 2017
Interview Descriptions: I applied shortly before Christmas 2016 and was contacted the first week of 2017 to schedule a phone interview.  The interview went well and questions regarding sales performance during previous positions were the main thrust.  The person that I spoke then said that they would forward my information to the local manager for their review and that they would be in contact with me to set up a second, in-person interview.  That was the first part of January.  It's now been over a month with no word from the initial phone interviewer, or the local manager.  I understand that hiring managers and HR personnel are inundated with questions, but to not contact a potential employee at all is downright unprofessional.
Interview Questions: How have you worked to increase your sales numbers at your current employer?

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Atlanta, GA) in Jan 2017
Interview Descriptions: I met with a panel of people. The panel included my supervisor, the VP of fundraising, and another woman who was leaving AHA because her husband's job required them to relocate. I received an email after applying where they asked me to come in for a face-to-face interview. Following the interview, they showed me around and introduced me to everyone.
Interview Questions: Tell me about yourself

title: Public Health Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at American Heart Association (New York, NY) in Jan 2017
Interview Descriptions: Phone interview was pretty basic, they asked me to walk them through my resume, followed by more questions. They had to explain the job for about 15 minutes, which ended up being quite different than the actual posting. It was more of a sales job. They forwarded me other job options afterwards so I had a feeling I wouldn't be offered the job.
Interview Questions: What are you short term and long term career goals.

title: Account Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Dallas, TX) in Jan 2017
Interview Descriptions: Phone interviews and in-person final interview.  Started with a phone call with HR, next a phone conversation with a regional manager and ended with a face to face interview with the regional manager in Dallas, TX.  Did research the company on their website and became familiar with their many courses offered to healthcare accounts.
Interview Questions: "Tell me a time" type questions.

title: Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at American Heart Association (San Diego, CA) in Jan 2017
Interview Descriptions: Very lengthy. Too many interviews with different staff members. Don't think they were truly interested in hiring outside of the company to begin with and only went through the steps as to not look bad.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work here

title: Development Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1+ week. I interviewed at American Heart Association in Jan 2017
Interview Descriptions: The overall phone interview with HR was extremely poor. It was clear the woman did not read anything that was submitted and did not ask any question in regards to my interest in the position. Overall she was in an extremely bad mood and made it seem like she did not care she was interviewing someone on a Friday. Very negative experience.
Interview Questions: Why did you leave your last job, are you full time or part time

title: Youth Market Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Houston, TX) in Nov 2016
Interview Descriptions: The HR Manager sent me a link to complete a video interview. I was asked 6 questions and asked to record a response. I was not given the questions ahead of time or any indication of what would be asked.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work with American Heart Association

title: Event Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Boston, MA) in Nov 2016
Interview Descriptions: The first step was to record a video online of myself answering preliminary questions. The only issue was that you were not able to review the video after it had been recorded.
Interview Questions: Please describe what you believe an administrative position is.

title: Director of Development Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Richmond, VA) in Nov 2016
Interview Descriptions: Interview was in steps. First over phone, immediately followed by a series of video questions that you had to film yourself answering. Timed and over the internet. Followed by sales profile analysis and in person interview a week later. Massive amount of questions. Very time consuming.
Interview Questions: What are your strengths and weaknesses?

title: Administrative Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Houston, TX)
Interview Descriptions: I was contacted by a recruiter and had a standard phone interview. About 3 days after the phone interview I received an online interview that asked questions about my skills and background.
Interview Questions: Standard interview questions

title: Business Development Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions: The interview process is very similar to those at other nonprofit organizations.  Upper management at the American Heart Association uses LinkedIn to find potential candidates so make sure to keep that up to date.  I hear the interview process is different between offices but, in general, there is usually a phone interview, and two in person interviews before the position is offered.
Interview Questions: What do you think will be the most challenging and most rewarding part of this job?

title: Director of Business Operations Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Wallingford, CT) in Oct 2016
Interview Descriptions: Had two personal interviews with different department heads. Both were friendly and asked good questions. They wanted a video interview but was not able to complete due to technical errors. Also had to take a personality test which I found very interesting.
Interview Questions: Why did I apply for the job.

title: Child Care Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 8 weeks. I interviewed at American Heart Association (Waltham, MA) in Oct 2016
Interview Descriptions: There were 3 components: a video interview, a phone interview, and a one-on-one interview.  The video interview was uncomfortable only because you are talking into a camera.  However, there was adequate information to prepare and a relatively quick response after the interview about the next steps.
Interview Questions: This position required that I work from home.  There were several questions about how I would prepare for and work through the home office scenario.

title: Fundraising Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at American Heart Association
Interview Descriptions:
The process took more THREE MONTHS.  I was offered the job, but I declined the offer.  Throughout the course of interviewing with them, I was obviously applying for and interviewing with other organizations. 

After applying online, someone from HR called to ask general questions about my experience.  After that, I was sent a link to take an online video interview.  There were five questions.  I was given 30 seconds to read the questions, and 2 minutes to answer.  No one was on the other end (it's just a recording).  The experience was a bit off-putting, but I survived.  After that, I had to fill out a personality profile which consisted of 350 questions.  A bit much to say the least.

After the video interview, I was invited to attend a panel interview.  There were three people in the room and the interview took about two hours.  Be prepared to talk about your resume in-depth.  You will be asked about every job you've listed (why you joined that organization, the relationship you had with your supervisor, the positives and negatives of the experience, why you left, etc).  The next step involved a phone interview with a higher level VP that lasted about one hour.  I was told at the end of that call that I was one of two final candidates.

Two weeks went by without a word.  I followed-up with all the appropriate parties after each interview.  Regardless of which way they went, I expected to hear something either way.  I continued to follow-up with them, but received no response.  After two weeks, she finally called.  When I told her I had accepted an offer with another organization, she was clearly upset.  She told me I was her top choice, but I was quick to remind her that I had made several attempts to connect with her and never received a response.
